description.narrative:
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra samhällsservice inom områdena vattenförsörjning, avloppsvattenhantering, avfallshantering, energieffektivisering, förnyelsebar energi och urbana allmänna transporter. Insatsen syftar till att stödja länderna i deras EU-integrering/tillnärmande, minska miljö- och klimatpåverkande utsläpp, förbättra hållbart nyttjande av naturresurser, institutionella reformer och förbättra hushållens tillgång till bra kommunal service.
Insatsen är ett samarbete mellan Sida och Europeiska Utvecklingsbanken (European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, EBRD) och är en vidareutvecklad fas 2 av ett program som startade år 2010 (med en allokering om 235 mkr). Insatsen, till vilket ett stöd om 100 MSEK beslutades i november 2014 och som nu utökas med 30 MSEK, är regional och omfattar länderna på Västra Balkan och i Östeuropa. Insatsen är en s k programmatiskt fond, där de enskilda projekten identifieras allteftersom parter i länderna och banken bedömer att förutsättningar finns att påbörja förhandlingar. Sidas stöd kan användas till reformarbete, systemförbättringar, tekniskt (technical cooperation) och finansiellt stöd (utvecklingslån/investeringsgåva). Projekten har omfattande finansieringspaket, men det finns alltid ett lån (marknadsmässigt) från EBRD och sedan kommer såväl part i land och andra givare eller finansiärer (banker) in i olika omfattning. Resultat i form av antal personer med tillgång till bättre kommunal service, minskade utsläpp, väl fungerande kommunala bolag etc. kommer att redovisas per projekt.

The objective of the contribution is to improve sustainable services in the areas of water supply, wastewater management, solid waste management, energy efficiency, district heating, renewable energy and urban public transports. The contribution aims to support the countries in their EU-integration/EU-approximation process, to reduce negative environmental and climate change impact, to increase sustainable use of natural resources, to introduce institutional reforms and to increase households access to good public services.
The contribution is a cooperation between Sida and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) and represents a phase 2 of a programme that started in 2010. The phase 2 contribution was agreed in Novemebr 2014 with a support of 100 MSEK and is not extended with a replenishment of 30 MSEK. The contribution is regional and includes the countries in the Western Balkans and in Eastern Europe. It is a "programmatic trust fund", whereby the projects are identified and approved with a no-objection procedure from Sida. Sida´s support can be used for technical assistance or for investment grants. All the projects with support from Sida are part of a larger investment package with loans from EBRD and often also with more financiers. Sida´s contribution is used to address affordability constraints, to introduce higher environmental/energy requirements and to ensure institutional reforms. Results will be reported on per project and in the form of number of persons benefiting from improved services, reforms introduced in the utilities etc. The programme is relevant from a poverty perspective since the grant allocation to the investments is justified through an affordability analysis reltated to the ability of the pooer segments of the population to be able to pay for basic municipal services. Access to affordable municipal services like water and wastewater, solid waste, heating and public transport are key to be able to get out of poverty but also contribute to an enabling environment for economic growth. Consultancy services for implementation support and project preparation will ensure projects are developed to give universal access to ssuch services and that discremination against poor through e.g. misuse of funds are avoided.

description.narrative: The results and progress accounted for below is focusing on the projects with CAPEX support. There are also a few projects with TC suppport only. Implementation of the projects supported from the fund is advancing, but at a slower rate of implementation than expected. Currently, 4 out of 11 projects receiving investment grants have been completed. Two projects in BiH have been completed but the remaining ones are facing many hurdles. Previously, it was decided to cancel the grant to Cazin. Recently, EBRD proposed to instead allocate funds to a regional solid waste project in Zivinice. The discussions are now at an advanced stage with the Embassy in Sarajevo for a possible co-financing of this project from their sources instead of using this fund. Since the loan finally became effective in June 2018, the Gradacac project has made some progress. The deadline set by the local Sida delegation for the Plava Voda project was not met by the client and a further request for extension has been received. The launch of the FOPIP consultant procurement was expected by the end of the year and EBRD questioned whether a further extension can be granted. Sida has advised, through the Embassy in Sarajevo which is responsible for the Sida contribution to the project, that they need to receive a formal request before such consideration can be made. The water sector projects in Belarus are proceeding but are facing many hurdles to handle. The Baranovichi biogas project has been completed, the projects in Slonim and Vitebsk are still under implementation. For the project in Orsha, construction works are yet to be commissioned. The Vitebsk and Orsha projects were both delayed due to the formation of a a regional Oblast owned utility in Vitebsk oblast covering all water utilities in the Oblast. For Duboko Solid waste project, Serbia, Sida has, through the Embassy in Belgrad, which is in charge of the financial contribution to the project, emphasized the importance of the timely signing of the legal documents. In case the project restructuring is further prolonged, Sida would not be interested in extension of the grant availability. Sida has also requested EBRD to provide an update on the investigation related to the broken pipe, for which an independent supervision engineer prepared the report. EBRD to provide a summary and update to the status of the concerned issue. Kvemo Kartli Municipal Solid Waste project, Georgia: The tender is expected to be launched in spring 2020 after which a specific timeline for implementation can be communicated. There are some uncommitted funds left. Sida will in dialogue and based on proposals from the EBRD look different options for project support to contribute to the programme results. Sida have communicated that remaining funds should be utilised for TC, to avoid entering into lengthy project engagement with CAPEX support at this late stage. A meeting is tentatively planned for spring 2020. The agreements for both SWME and SWM2 (Fund phase 1 and 2 i.e.) was amended in December 2019 to reflect the joint decision in moving to annual reporting starting from 2020. Effectively, this will mean that there will be no narrative reporting during 2020. The next report, covering 2020 will be submitted in spring 2021. Further, the agreement for SWM2 was extend until 31 December 2022 to enable utilisation of remaining funds.
